item.description:
John Jeavons is the Executive Director of Ecology Action in Northern California.  He is known internationally as the leading researcher and method developer, teacher, and consultant for the small-scale, sustainable agricultural method known as GROW BIOINTENSIVE mini-farming. He has authored, co-authored or edited over 30 publications on this high-yielding, resource-conserving Biointensive approach, including a five-part, peer reviewed article that appeared in The Journal of Sustainable Agriculture. Jeavons' food-raising methods are being used in 141 countries and by such organizations as UNICEF, Save the Children, and the Peace Corps.

 

At the 2012 NOFA/Mass Winter Conference, on SATURDAY, JANUARY 14th, Jeavons will be outlining a detailed Crop Succession Management Plan in accordance with the principles of GROW BIOINTENSIVE ®. The three-part all-day seminar will be a great opportunity for commercial farmers, master gardeners, or urban homesteaders to get the most from their soil, while decreasing water-use and building soil fertility.  To register for the NOFA/Mass Winter Conference, go to www.nofamass.org/conferences/winter/ . 

 

The seminar runs in three workshop segments from 9:00 AM -5:30 PM,  and will take place at Worcester State University.  Seminar cost is $110 per person.  Scholarships are available for Beginning Farmers (farming 10 years or less), and Early-Bird Discount for registering by January 1st.  Questions?  Email  wc@nofamass.org, or call 978-355-2853.
